citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Oceanicola granulosus sp. nov.
Oceanicola granulosus (gra.nu.lo′sus. N.L. masc. adj. granulosus granular).
The description of this species is the same as that for the genus.
Cells are 1·1–2·1 μm wide and 0·5–1·0 μm long.
Colonies are 0·5–1·0 mm in diameter, uniformly circular, convex and opaque.
Temperature range for growth is 4–40 °C, optimum 28 °C.
pH range for growth is 5·5–9·5, optimum 7·5–8·0.
The sole carbon source utilization patterns for differentiating strains are listed in Table 1 and the text.

According to Biolog tests, the following substrates were oxidized by all strains: glycogen, Tween 80, N-acetyl-d-glucosamine, d-arabitol, d-cellobiose, d-galactose, gentiobiose, α-d-glucose, maltose, sucrose, d-trehalose, xylitol, pyruvic acid methyl ester, acetic acid, citric acid, formic acid, α-ketobutyric acid, α-ketoglutaric acid, l-lactic acid, propionic acid, l-alanine, l-glutamic acid, l-serine, inosine, uridine and 2,3-butanediol.
Predominant fatty acids are 16 : 0 (12–13 %), 18 : 1ω7c (55–63 %), methyl 18 : 1 (8–11 %) and cyclo 19 : 0 (11–13 %).
Isolated from the western Sargasso Sea, Atlantic Ocean.
Type strain is strain HTCC2516T (=ATCC BAA-861T=DSM 15982T=KCTC 12143T).
